articleBody.value: Judge Johnny Hardwick will hear arguments about why he should reconsider the sentence he gave to Tremayne Moorer, former athletic adviser at Alabama State University, who pleaded guilty to domestic violence.
On Jan. 17, Hardwick sentenced Moorer to 15 years - five of that to be served in prison, the remainder on probation.
Just before he was sentenced, Raven Hicks, Moorer’s ex-wife, described to the court the night Moorer abused her.

“You tortured me,” she said. “I laid in my bed. You came and got on top of me and put a gun to my head and you told me, ‘I’m going to kill you and then I’m going to kill myself.’ You beat me. Tremayne, you told me that you had written my name on the bullets. You told me that you were going to allow me to Facetime my family one last time.”
Hicks’ little sister testified that Raven was able to call her on the night of Oct. 20, 2015.
“I heard Tremayne telling my sister he was going to kill her. … I was able to call 911. There’s no telling what would have happened if I wasn’t able to call the police,” she said.

At least nine people spoke on Moorer’s behalf, asking the court for mercy and testifying that this act of violence was out of character for him. His character witnesses included ASU head men’s basketball coach Lewis Jackson and head volleyball coach Penny Lucas-White.
Moorer, 6-foot-6, 210 pounds, played basketball for ASU until 2011.

Tremayne’s attorney has filed a motion asking Hardwick to reconsider the sentence, and allow Moorer to serve those five years in Community Corrections instead of in prison. Community corrections offers an alternative to serving a prison sentence, and could instead allow Tremayne to serve his sentence through alternative means such as a work release program.

Moorer’s filings state that he has been attending domestic violence counseling, has completed a conflict resolution program through ASU and, ‘has even gone as far as to establish his own domestic violence awareness program.” It also states that Moorer has lost his employment as a result of the conviction.
Hardwick has set the reconsideration hearing for Feb. 23.

articleBody.value: Looking for the DeLorean? Just go around the cosplay contest, through the geek merch and past the video game tournament. If you run into the Stormtroopers, you’ve gone too far.
Yes, that’s all really happening and, yes, it’s going to happen in Montgomery.

The first Gump City Comic Con is set for August 12 under the gold dome of the Alcazar Shrine Temple on East Boulevard. Even in its inaugural year, the multi-genre pop culture expo plans to bring an ambitious showcase of all things geek to the Capital City, including a few celebrity guests.
But its founder says this is only the beginning.

“I'm actually overwhelmed by all of the positive vibes from the community and folks reaching out,” con founder J.R. Austin said. “… There's not a doubt in my mind that this show will be fantastic even in its first year and will only get better each year.”

For now, Austin and other con organizers are working to fill about 16,000 square feet at the temple with as much fun as they can. The lineup so far includes DJs in the main hall, concessions, a gaming tournament sponsored by GTSouth Geek & Gaming Tavern, cosplay experts running a public costume contest and much more. Even Stormtroopers from the 501st Legion will be there.
Plans are in the works for some other “special guests,” but Austin said it’s too early to name-drop.

The unaffiliated Comic-Con International in San Diego regularly brings in more than 100,000 people and has become an annual pop culture touchstone. Don't expect GCCC to be anywhere near that big, at least not yet. After all, that one started in 1970.
But GTSouth owner Mike Taylor said it’s an idea that’s overdue for Montgomery and one that can flourish here. He thinks it could bring in geeks from across the region.
“When the bigger ones happen, like Dragon Con in Atlanta, I lose all my customers,” Taylor said.
“(GCCC) is at a time when the others aren’t going on, so everybody’s looking for a con to go to. Based on the feedback, I think it’ll just grow and get bigger.”
Austin goes to cons all across the country as the owner of Keeps 4 Geeks, a geek culture swag vendor. But he’s also a Troy University graduate with deep roots in the Montgomery area.
He said he’s always been into anime, video games, comics, cards and so on, and was part of the crowd making the pilgrimage from Montgomery to conventions in Atlanta.

“I wondered for years why the capital of our great state with as many geeks as we have here has never had a show,” he said. “Later, I found out there were a couple that had come and gone, but no one was invested in building the geek community here and making great strides to bring our people together.”
He said friends who help organize other conventions urged him to get one started here.
Expect to hear a lot more about the con in the months ahead, including guests and ticket prices. You can follow updates on their Facebook page.
“It will definitely be a good bit of stuff to see and do, and we're trying to make sure we give people a good bang for their buck,” Austin said.
What is Gump City Comic Con?

It’s unaffiliated with San Diego Comic-Con or any other gathering, but it’s in the same vein. It’s a Montgomery-based pop culture expo and celebration of all things geeky. Some of the things you can expect to see:

• Elaborate outfits and a cosplay contest
  • Tables full of merchandise and swag
  • A video game tournament and tabletop gaming
  • Stormtroopers from the 501st Legion
  • DeLorean and “Ghostbusters” photo ops
  • Special guests (names coming soon)

articleBody.value: The Alabama Legislature will return to work Feb. 7. It was clear Wednesday that the seemingly endless anxieties about adequate funding will, too.

Representatives from the courts and law enforcement services presented their budget and legislative needs for the coming year to members of the House and Senate Judiciary committees, urging them to give them adequate funding to enforce the law and make fast and judicious decisions in court cases.

Several speakers said the funding issue was acute. Barry Matson, director of the Office of Prosecution Services, told the committee members that the state’s share of funding for the state’s district attorneys had fallen to about 26 percent of their total funding. The remainder, he said, had to come from local fees, including court costs, which he said would be a long-term “disaster.”
Because of requirements for certain funding to be in place, Matson said, the Office of Prosecution Services almost ran out of funding in the first quarter of last year.
“Our funding crisis is at a point where last quarter we were within an hour of bouncing every paycheck for every prosecutor in Alabama,” Matson said.
Matson said the office would look for legislation to help fight the inflow of heroin into the state, including heroin mixed with fentanyl, an opioid mixed with heroin to increase its potency.

The Alabama Department of Corrections will also press forward with an $800 million proposal to replace many prison facilities with four new ones – three for male inmates, each to house 4,000 people, and a new women’s facility. Commissioner Jeff Dunn gave the committee an overview of the proposal – which failed on the last day of the 2016 regular session – and said one reason to approve it was the growing violence in the state’s overcrowded prisons.
The prison system, Dunn said, was “increasing the amount of risk we accept. That’s very troubling.”

Corrections faces many challenges, including overcrowding; a 20 percent drop in the number of corrections officers in the system and lawsuits that could lead to the release of prisoners, orders to increase spending, or both. Asked about the presence of contraband in the system, Dunn said that reflected overcrowding and understaffing.
“It takes people to prevent contraband from getting into the facilities,” he said.
Legislative committees will begin formal budget hearings next week in advance of the legislative session.

articleBody.value: PRATTVILLE — The phone call reminded Julie Harrington of a 27-year-old basketball feat and brought a little surprise.
Harrington, until her phone rang, didn’t know that her 56-point game for Trinity in 1990 was a Montgomery city record.
Only, by then, it no longer was.
Brewbaker Tech senior Bianca Jackson relegated Harrington to second place on the city list, scoring 58 points in an 85-38 victory Friday at Greenville.
“That’s what records are made for — to be broken,” Harrington said Monday. “It pushes people to be even better.
Harrington’s 56 points came in a 95-46 first-round Class 2A substate win over Calera on Feb. 17, 1990, the same day G.W. Carver’s Merlakia Jones scored a mere 48 in a 6A substate game.

Trinity followed with a win over Beulah before losing to St. James in the state quarterfinals. In 1990, girls teams played three substate rounds at campus sites before the state semifinals in Decatur.
It all capped Harrington’s basketball playing career.
“The funny thing is I don’t even remember the 56, but I remember the first two,” Harrington said, harkening back to her first career points as a Trinity seventh-grader.
They came at Highland Home on an outside shot.
“We didn’t have the 3-point line then,” Harrington said, “but it would have been close.”

She finished with 2,170 career points, including 50 one night against Montgomery Academy when she didn’t play the fourth quarter. She was part of a state runner-up team — and Trinity will honor its 1988 Wildcats at a Feb. 7 banquet.
She was a second-team Class 2A All-State player as a senior and never played competitive basketball again. Harrington went to Auburn as a regular student.
“I loved basketball, but part of that was playing with my closest friends,” Harrington said. “I realized it would be different in college.”
Harrington graduated in elementary education and has taught in Elmore County and Montgomery.

Today, she’s 44 and a seventh-year principal at Prattville’s Daniel Pratt Elementary. Bianca Jackson, on the other hand, is 13 points shy of the 2,000th of her career, is a South Carolina signee and plays at Prattville on Thursday.
“That was all a great part of growing up,” said Harrington, who coached some youth teams but says she’s “absolutely retired from coaching.”
“On the right day,” Harrington said, “I absolutely can.”

content.headline: From 56 to 58: Former record holder lauds Jackson's 58

articleBody.value:
New lawsuits were filed this week in Alabama and three other states on behalf of women who say they were victimized as teenagers when they were sold for sex on an international website.
The suits filed in Alabama, California, Texas and Washington are believed to be the first to individually name the operators of Backpage.com, Seattle attorney Jason Amala said in an email.
Chief executive officer Carl Ferrer and purported owners Michael Lacey and James Larkin are among those being sued, along with other affiliated individuals and holding companies.
The complaints say the three men are liable because they knew they were profiting from illegal sex trafficking.
Backpage's general counsel, Liz McDougall, declined comment.
The men appeared in a California courtroom earlier this week to contest similar criminal charges that they say are barred by federal law and free speech protections.
Amala has a separate lawsuit against the company awaiting trial after it survived a legal challenge that reached the Washington state Supreme Court. But the U.S. Supreme Court this month left in place a different lower-court ruling that said Backpage's ads are protected by federal law because the site is publishing advertisements created by clients.
The four new lawsuits are the first to be filed since Backpage shuttered its adult services section earlier this month as a U.S. Senate subcommittee issued a report alleging that the site's operators were actively editing ads, not merely publishing them.
The five women allege they were advertised on Backpage.com between 2013 and late 2015:

• The Alabama woman says she was 17 when her advertisements ran in Houston County, Alabama, in 2013.
  • The two women who filed the Washington lawsuit say they were between 14 and 16 years old when they were sold for sex in the Seattle area.
  • The California suit is on behalf of a teenager who says she was 15 when she was advertised in Riverside County in August 2015.
  • The Texas suit was filed because that is where Backpage was headquartered at the time another teenager says she was trafficked in Hawaii in 2015.

articleBody.value: If your long, lost grandson calls and asks you for money, you might want to call the police.
If the police call you and ask for money, you should still hang up and call the police.

Two new telephone scams are being reported across Alabama currently, according to the Alabama Law Enforcement Agency and the Montgomery County Sheriff’s Office. Last year, scammers pretended to be Alabama Power or the IRS in an attempt to scare people into thinking a payment was past due. This year, swindlers have taken on a new approach and two new fake identities: Montgomery County Sheriff’s officers and a down-on-his-luck grandson.
The latter is reportedly targeting senior citizens and is being investigated by the State Bureau of Investigation, according to ALEA.

“SBI Agents warn citizens to be suspicious of callers asking for money in any form. In this case, each victim received a call from someone posing as their grandson who is in financial trouble and is requesting assistance in the form of Walmart gift cards,” said ALEA Cpl. Jesse Thornton in a release.
While the scam might seem unlikely to work, ALEA has identified three victims in Etowah, Jackson and Washington counties who were swindled out of a combined $13,000.
Thornton said the "grandsons" are requesting money in the form of a Walmart gift card.

In Montgomery County, an old scam has taken on new life as people are receiving calls from scammers operating under the actual names of Montgomery County Sheriff's officers, MCSO Capt. George Beaudry said.

"They’re calling people saying (for example), 'I am Beaudry and you have a warrant for your arrest, and the only way you're not going to jail is if you send this dollar amount to this account or this location,'" Beaudry said.

In previous years, scammers posed as Montgomery Police Department officers or hijacked the phone number of the Autauga County Sheriff’s Office to scare locals into believing they had a warrant out for their arrest due to past due fees.
This year Beaudry said his department has received "quite a few" calls from citizens who are confused about what seem to be MCSO's new fee-collecting tactics.

“Somebody I know personally called me and left a message saying a sergeant — and they had his name and everything — had called them pursuant to an investigation and said that if they didn’t pay this amount they would be arrested,” Beaudry said. “It’s something happening fairly regularly...The thing we want to get out there is we don't handle business like that at all. Most law enforcement agencies don't handle business like that."

Like most telephone scams, the caller will not accept credit or debit cards over the phone (which is also one sign that it is indeed a scam). Instead the caller will suggest cash be sent via MoneyGram or a Green Dot card.

Hamburger King owner Gay Harrison was the target of an Alabama Power scam last year. It was an elaborate scam that even played a recording of the Alabama Power menu when the number was called back. After being told her check for her previous power bill was lost, Harrison went to a CVS to attempt to transfer money to the con artist.
“It then clicked in my mind that it wasn’t Alabama Power,” Harrison told the Montgomery Advertiser last year. “I came within one minute of being scammed out of $578.”

When uncertain about the veracity of the person calling you, the best solution is to get the caller’s name, hang up, and call the number you normally use for that person or place of business to verify that an account is past due. If the caller claims to be your long-lost grandson, ask them how his parents are and why he only calls to ask for money.

In both situations, fear and a sense of urgency are tools of the con. Beaudry advised anybody who receives a strange phone call to remain calm and verify who it is they're speaking with before making a rash decision.

“I think they just prey on fear. People are afraid when they hear the words, ‘We are going to arrest you,’ and I suspect they are using that, because some people are sending money when they hear those words,” Beaudry said. “Don’t call the number they leave for you. Find the actual phone number for the agency and call them directly and speak to somebody.”

content.subHead: Two new telephone scams are being reported in Montgomery and across Alabama with scammers claiming to be either Montgomery Co. Sheriff's officers or a grandson in need of cash.

storyHighlights: Know which fees you haven't paid. This will give you peace of mind and prevent uncertainty and, in turn, rash decisions.
If told by a caller that a bill must be paid or money must be transferred, verify with the local office/number you normally use to pay bills.
Don't panic. Don't allow someone to rush you into giving money. Scammer or not, if somebody says you have one hour to pay a fee, use that hour to verify that you actually have a fee to pay.

articleBody.value: MOBILE — Here’s a public service announcement on Ryan Anderson by those who know him best: Don’t talk smack unless you are willing to pay the consequences.

The Alabama linebacker is known for his hard-hitting approach on the field, and he has no problem providing constant reminders to those unfortunate enough to forget that. So, when he was asked Tuesday during the Senior Bowl workouts in Mobile if he’s received any digs from fellow South Team linebacker Ben Boulware whose Clemson Tigers beat the Crimson Tide in the national championship game earlier this month, Anderson’s answer was simple.
“He ain't gone say nothin’ ’bout that game,” Anderson said without flashing so much as a smile. “That’ll start a fight.”

That sounds about right to former Daphne High School head football coach Glenn Vickery, who coached Anderson throughout high school. Vickery, who retired from Daphne last year, remembers some of those moments when someone said the wrong thing to Anderson at the wrong time.

The story Vickery likes to tell most occurred at the end of a season at Daphne where the starters were going up against the scout team. The former coach said it was already hard to reel Anderson in during practice. So, after one of the scout-team players got into it with the linebacker, things escalated pretty quickly.
“Apparently a little freshman said something to Ryan, and the next thing I know he’s body slamming people to the ground,” Vickery said. “That’s sort of Ryan. Don’t talk smack to him.”

Vickery made the short 15-mile trip from Daphne to Mobile on Tuesday to attend Anderson’s first practice at the Senior Bowl, relishing the opportunity to reconnect with one of his former player’s during his return home.

Throughout their four years together at Daphne, Vickery and Anderson developed almost a father-son relationship. Preparing to play in his final football game in the state of Alabama, the star linebacker has an appreciation of not only where it all started for him but also the coach who helped develop him into a man.

“He was always hard on me. He never let up on me,” Anderson recalled of Vickery. “He definitely taught me a lot of valuable lessons from having a coach there all times no matter how good I was. He always held me to a certain level, and if didn’t I do what he wanted me to, he’d send me off out of practice. He’d put me on the second or third team. We butted heads some, but it was all out of love, and I love him and I thank him for it.”

Those clashes often occurred from moments such as the scout-team incident. Vickery said while Anderson never really showed any attitude problems, the linebacker would often allow himself to get overaggressive during practice.

Coaching at a powerhouse like Daphne, Vickery had no place for that on his team. However, instead of getting into his face or yelling at him, the head coach learned quickly the best way to get through to Anderson was to take away the thing he loved most – football. Vickery said he used to send Anderson home following dustups early in his high school career.
It didn’t take long for those lessons to sink in.

Michael Pierce Jr., who was a defensive end at Daphne with Anderson before playing in college at Tulane and Samford, said he remembers seeing a change in Anderson’s maturity as he progressed through Vickery’s system.

“It’s been amazing to watch,” Pierce said. “Especially as a 10th-grader, having seen him get kicked out of practice and knowing it was one of my brothers, it’s tough. But I think everything worked out, maybe even better than he would have planned. We knew he had the physical tools to be the player he is today, he just had to grow up a little bit, and man it’s amazing to see him now.”

Anderson finished last season as one of the Tide’s most prolific players, compiling a team-high 19 tackles for a loss, including nine sacks. While not always the most vocal player, he stepped up in the locker room by leading through example.

“He was a really good leader on our team,” Alabama head coach Nick Saban said. “He’s a very, very consistent performer. He can probably play inside backer or outside backer, and he has some pass-rush abilities. He’s a guy that creates a lot of value for a team.”
Some of that value went unnoticed this season. Anderson was not named an All-American and failed to receive the same accolades as his teammates despite putting up equally impressive stats.
To no surprise, that didn’t sit too well with the star linebacker.

“I set goals for myself and I worked hard to achieve them,” Anderson said. “I feel like a lot of that stuff ended up put in a lot of other people’s hands, and I can’t control that. It definitely did put a chip on my shoulder, it pisses me off a little bit, man. I went into the playoffs, every day I’d write MVP of the new season in my notes. That’s what I wanted to do, I wanted to be MVP of every game we played in the playoffs and just let people know.”

Anderson earned defensive MVP of the Peach Bowl against Washington, tallying three tackles and returning an interception for a touchdown. He was equally impressive in the national championship game against Clemson, tallying seven tackles with two for a loss and one sack while recovering two fumbles.

Now he’s looking to show NFL he’s not one to be overlooked. Anderson, 6-foot-2, 258 pounds, is projected to be selected early in the second round of the NFL draft in April. However, with a solid performance in front of NFL scouts this week, he could jump into the first round.

“I’m just here to put a cap on my season, answer any questions that people had about me,” Anderson said. “I’m a competitor, I’m willing to go put anything on display. I’m not a gym-short, Olympic-type guy, that stuff is not really football. It’s camps and drills, that’s one thing I got to learn. Right now, this is my last chance to show coaches I’m a football player.”
It’s also one more chance to give back to the community that helped raise him and an opportunity to reflect on the people who helped him get to this point.

“Being able to give back to the community, I feel like I was meant to play in this game,” Anderson said. “I always wanted to play in it, I grew up watching it. It’s just a blessing, it’s a humbling experience and it’s a great opportunity.”

articleBody.value: Saturday’s high school boys basketball tripleheader at Faulkner will still include a No. 1 team.
It just won’t be Robert E. Lee.
The Generals, after last weekend’s loss at Sidney Lanier, relinquished their one-week hold on the top spot in the Alabama Sports Writers Association rankings.
Lee (23-2), after spiraling three spots to No. 4, will meet new No. 1 Hoover (22-4) at 6:30 p.m. Saturday.
The tripleheader begins at 5 p.m. when Park Crossing (12-7) takes on Huffman (16-7), which is ranked sixth in 7A.

At 6:30 p.m., G.W. Carver rekindles its one-sided rivalry with Mountain Brook. The Wolverines (14-6) have lost their last three meetings with the Spartans (22-3), including twice in the state tournament.
Carver is ranked sixth in 6A, while Mountain Brook is second in 7A.

Of course, the three Montgomery teams first have games Friday, including Lee making a visit to Carver. The Generals snapped a 17-game losing streak to the Wolverines last month in the championship game Carver’s post-Christmas tournament.
This week’s Alabama Sports Writers Association high school basketball rankings:

articleBody.value:
Federal prosecutors say two owners of psychological service companies have been convicted of an $8.9 million fraud scheme that billed Medicare for unnecessary or nonexistent tests on nursing home patients in four Gulf Coast states.
Attorneys said that Slidell, Louisiana, residents Rodney Hesson and his mother, 63-year-old Gertrude Parker, plan to appeal.
Each owned companies in Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi and Florida.
A jury convicted them this week of conspiracy to commit health care fraud and of conspiracy to make false statements about health care. According to the news release, the jurors also found them responsible for $8.9 million in fraudulent payments.
Two psychologists who worked for them pleaded guilty last year, admitting $5.6 million in fraudulent claims.

articleBody.value: The Environmental Health Division of the Alabama Department of Public Health permits and inspects all food service establishments located within the county.
Inspection scores reflect compliance with minimum health standards only at the time of the inspection.
Scoring between 85 and 100: Establishments are considered to be in satisfactory compliance and are inspected on routine schedule.
Scoring between 70 and 84: Establishments require a follow-up inspection within 60 days.
Scoring 60-69: Establishments require follow-up and re-inspection within 48 hours.
FREE DOWNLOAD: Go Play 334 app delivers latest on River Region dining, nightlife

These food service establishments were inspected by the Montgomery County Health Department. The establishments are judged on a 100-point scale. Inspections are quarterly unless a site scores less than 85. All that score lower than 85 are reinspected monthly. Establishments, addresses and scores follow. The scores also can be found at www.adph.org/montgomery.

articleBody.value: Much of what you do as a successful investor will result in you paying more in taxes. Close out an investment for a profit? Pay a capital gains tax. Receive a dividend? Pay a dividend tax. Own a mutual fund? Pay taxes on those year-end distributions. But there's one incredibly smart move you can make as an investor that can potentially cut $4,500 -- or maybe even more -- from your 2017 tax bill.

That move? Contribute to your traditional 401(k) at work. Every penny you contribute to your traditional 401(k) plan reduces your taxable income, which reduces the income tax you pay during the year you contribute it. Even better, that money grows tax deferred until withdrawn from your account, meaning those previous investment successes won't trigger immediate taxes on money that remains in your plan.
How much can you cut your 2017 taxes?

The tax benefit you get from contributing depends on how much you contribute and what marginal tax bracket that money would have otherwise fallen in. The table below shows your potential tax savings from contributing the maximum allowed by current rules (though your contribution may be further limited, particularly if you're considered a "highly compensated employee"):

2017 Contribution Limit

$18,000

$24,000

Tax Savings, 10% Bracket

$1,800

$2,400

Tax Savings, 15% Bracket

$2,700

$3,600

Tax Savings, 25% Bracket

$4,500

$6,000

Tax Savings, 28% Bracket

$5,040

$6,720

Tax Savings, 33% Bracket

$5,940

$7,920

Tax Savings, 35% Bracket

$6,300

$8,400

Tax Savings, 39.6% Bracket

$7,128

$9,504
Data source: U.S. Internal Revenue Service. Table by author. Tax savings assumes contribution at the listed limit and that all deducted income would have fallen in the listed bracket.

There are two ways to look at the tax benefit you get from contributing to your traditional 401(k). First, the direct benefit is that the tax check you'll have to write to Uncle Sam will be that much lower thanks to your contribution reducing your taxable income.

Second, the money you're contributing is that much less expensive for you than contributing it to an after-tax brokerage account. If you contribute $18,000 to your traditional 401(k) plan and are in the 25% tax bracket, the $4,500 tax reduction means the contribution only cost you the equivalent of $13,500 in after-tax cash.
Save taxes now, build a nest egg for tomorrow

Even more important than the tax savings that come from contributing to your traditional 401(k) plan is the fact that the money you contribute to that plan can grow, tax deferred, for your future. If you want an idea of how quickly your money can grow, consider using the shorthand trick known as the Rule of 72. You simply divide 72 by the rate of return you expect to earn with your money, and the result will estimate how long it will take your money to double for you.

For instance, if you expect to earn 8% per year, you'd divide 72 by 8 to end up with 9 -- indicating that your money would double in about 9 years. Likewise, if you're expecting 6% annual returns, you'd divide 72 by 6 and figure out that your money would double in about 12 years. Over the long run, stock market returns have been in the neighborhood of 10% per year, which, by the rule of 72, would indicate your invested money could potentially double every 7.2 years.

Using those estimates, if you have 30 or so years left until you retire, that 10% return rate would mean your money could potentially double about four times over. With a single doubling, $10,000 turns into $20,000. With a second doubling, it becomes $40,000. With a third doubling, it'd turn into $80,000, and with a fourth doubling, that initial $10,000 investment would become a whopping $160,000.

With all of that potential doubling taking place inside your 401(k) plan, your money can continue to grow for you tax deferred until it's time for you to withdraw it in retirement. Even better, all of that growth is possible from a single year's investment. You will likely be able to invest in your 401(k) at work every year you're employed, making your 401(k) plan a great tool to potentially propel you to millionaire status by retirement. That's the real power of contributing to your 401(k) at work.

The ideal time to start saving for your retirement is the day you draw your first paycheck. The next best time is right now, this very instant. The sooner you get started, the more potential doubling cycles your money can go through before you need to spend it to cover your costs. So, take the first step today, and set yourself up for a far better future than you otherwise would have had. The potential for $4,500 (or maybe even more) in tax savings is just icing on the cake.
Chuck Saletta has no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool has no position in any of the stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool has a disclosure policy.

The Motley Fool is a USA TODAY content partner offering financial news, analysis and commentary designed to help people take control of their financial lives. Its content is produced independently of USA TODAY.

content.shortHeadline: Can you cut $4,500 from your 2017 tax bill?
content.about: Much of what you do as a successful investor will result in you paying more in taxes. Close out an investment for a profit? Pay a capital gains tax. Receive a dividend? Pay a dividend tax. Own a mutual fund? Pay taxes on those year-end distributions. But there's one incredibly smart move you can make as an investor that can potentially cut $4,500 -- or maybe even more -- from your 2017 tax bill.That move? Contribute to your traditional 401(k) at work. Every penny you contribute to your traditional 401(k) plan reduces your taxable income, which reduces the income tax you pay during the year you contribute it. Even better, that money grows tax deferred until withdrawn from your account, meaning those previous investment successes won't trigger immediate taxes on money that remains in your plan.

articleBody.value: Tostitos may not be advertising in this year's Super Bowl, but it still plans to have its presence felt during, and after, the "Big Game."

In an attempt to raise awareness for responsible driving, the chip maker has partnered with Mother's Against Drunk Driving and Uber to create "alcohol sensor bags," special Tostitos bags that can tell if you've been drinking while watching the Patriots take on the Falcons.

"We wanted to make sure that as people were celebrating, they were also partying responsibly," says Jennifer Saenz, chief marketing officer for Tostitos maker Frito-Lay. "We thought it was an opportunity to begin a conversation with consumers about drinking and driving, and about responsibility, in a really fun and engaging way."

As nifty as it sounds, don't look for these at your local grocery. The bags won't be sold to the public, though USA TODAY was able to get its hands on one of them and can confirm that it does indeed work.
The bag is not a breathalyzer and won't give you an exact measurement of your blood alcohol level, instead opting to look for traces of adult beverages in your breath.

A sensor at the top measures your breath, while lights below the logo flash the results. If the bag doesn't detect alcohol, the front will light up green. If alcohol is present then the front of the bag will flash a red steering wheel with a "don't drink and drive" message along the bottom.
On the plus side, the front will also flash an Uber code that you can use to get a discount for an Uber ride to help get you home.

"We wanted to really think beyond the Super Bowl, beyond Houston, and think about what impact we could make in other settings," says Saenz about the inspiration behind the bag. "For us it was a pretty natural thought to land on those parties that people are having on gameday," continues Saenz, noting that "more often than not there's alcoholic beverages there."

While Frito-Lay won't be selling the bags, the company will be giving out 25,000 $10 Uber discounts to those who purchase any of its chips between now and the Super Bowl as part of its effort to make sure people get home safely.
The codes, which will work for both new and existing Uber users, can be activated by simply typing in the last five digits of the bag of chips' UPC barcode after the Super Bowl ends.

To help further raise awareness for the partnership the company has partnered with Tennessee Titans tight end Delanie Walker on a video spot. Walker lost an aunt and uncle to a drunk driver following the 2013 Super Bowl, which he played in as a member of the San Francisco 49ers.
"We want to make sure everyone gets home safely," says Saenz.

content.author: Eli Blumenthal, USA TODAY

articleBody.value: WETUMPKA – An Elmore County jury on Thursday is expected  to get the case of a former American Idol contestant facing almost a dozen child pornography charges.

Brandon Cox, 26, of Wetumpka, is charged with seven counts of possession of obscene material depicting persons less than 17-years-old and two counts of intent to distribute obscene material depicting persons less than 17-years-old, courthouse records reflect.

Cox was a 2012 American Idol contestant. He was cut from the show during the group round during Hollywood Week,  reports show. His attorney, Kenny James, was in court Wednesday on another case, and could not be reached for comment. He did not return phone calls to his law office seeking comment.
Cox allegedly had 200 videos and 40 images of child pornography on his computer, courthouse records show.

The investigation of Cox began in 2011 and he was indicted on the charges in 2015, court records show. Testimony in the case began Tuesday. The case will resume Thursday because James had a scheduling conflict.

articleBody.value: “First Lady of the Revolution: A Southern Belle’s Journey Through Love, Exile and Revolution” may be partially about what writer/director/producer Andrea Kalin calls historic “Hemisphere-rocking events,” but it is the other revolt – the one taking place in a young, adventurous Southern woman – that will most fascinate viewers.

It would be easy to say that is the story of an unsophisticated, Alabama woman swept up in the winds of history, except that implies that Henrietta Boggs, now Henrietta Boggs MacGuire, was acted upon and not in control, instead of making the conscious decisions that took her into a foreign land, danger and history.

Her transformation from a somewhat sheltered Southern belle to one of the leaders of a historic revolution is told by her so matter-of-factly that it makes her independence and bravery all-the-more impressive.
The documentary examines Costa Rica and MacGuire as both take a journey of independence. But for Southern viewers, it will be MacGuire’s journey that will be by far the more fascinating.

Through interviews, largely with her, her children, historians and those who took part in the revolution, we see her transformation from a young lady in a conservative Presbyterian family taking part in the social traditions of Birmingham’s then-segregated Southern College to a firebrand taking part in a Costa Rican revolution that eventually resulted in her becoming the country’s first lady.

Her escape from Southern societal norms occurred after her parents allowed her to visit an aunt and uncle who had retired to Costa Rica. There she met Jose Figueres Ferrer, a motorcycle-riding Costa Rican coffee farmer, whom she soon married. After her husband criticized the president of Costa Rica, the couple was exiled. Ferrer later returned to lead a 1948 revolution that overthrew the corrupt government and later restored democracy to the country.

During all this MacGuire was more than simply the wife of a powerful man. She helped shape social policies, successfully pushing for Costa Rica to give women the right to vote and more opportunities for education.

But after her husband became so consumed with Costa Rican politics that he had no time for her or their children, she divorced him and returned to the United States. After working in Washington, she moved back to Alabama in 1969, where she remarried, co-founded River Region Living magazine and contributed articles to the Montgomery Advertiser.

It’s a remarkable story, and the interviews with MacGuire are wonderful. Although in her 90s, age seems to have had no effect on her wit and intelligence, and it is easy to catch glimpses of the fearless young woman who so easily shrugged off the Southern conformity of the 1940s.

It’s a fascinating documentary. It’s biggest problem is that it leaves viewers hungering for more information than they receive. Although it has a brief scene at the end of the documentary showing MacGuire interviewing McDowell Lee, who was Secretary of the Alabama Senate for close to half a century, for the most part the story ends when she divorces Ferrer and leaves Costa Rica.

While the story ends, our curiosity does not. We still want to know a multitude of things: What was it like returning to the U.S. and how did her family react? What was the rest of Ferrer’s life like, and what was her relationship with him like in the years after the divorce? How did her second husband compare to the first and what did he think about her earlier life? What were her feelings about living in Montgomery after spending those years in revolution-torn Costa Rica?
While the documentary doesn’t ask those questions, if you attend the Sunday premiere of “First Lady of the Revolution,” you can.

MacGuire, who with Kalin will attend the 3 p.m. showing at the Capri Theatre, will answer audience questions after the screening, which is sponsored by Montgomery’s Landmarks Foundation. Tickets are $30 and available at Old Alabama Town, NewSouth Books and immediately before the show at the Capri ticket window.

“First Lady of the Revolution,” racked up three awards at Birmingham’s Sidewalk Film Festival, including the Audience Award for Best Alabama Film. MacGuire was given the festival’s Inaugural Spirit of Sidewalk Award.
WHAT: Premiere of “First Lady of the Revolution” with Henrietta Boggs MacGuire, and Director Andrea Kalin
COST: Tickets are $30 and available at Old Alabama Town, NewSouth Books and immediately before the show at the Capri ticket window.

content.author: Rick Harmon, Special to the Advertiser

articleBody.value: CECIL — Abby Ray’s 18 points helped Lowndes Academy take a 41-27 win over Kingwood on Wednesday in the AISA Class A, Region 1 tournament at Macon-East.
Madolynn Headley posted seven points and 12 rebounds for the Rebels (14-4), who take on Autauga Academy at 9 a.m. Friday in the semifinals.
With Wednesday’s win, Lowndes clinched a berth in next week’s AISA state quarterfinals.
The Rebels have advanced to the quarterfinals 16 times in the last 18 years. Over the last four seasons, Lowndes has two state titles and two runner-up finishes.
The AISA state quarterfinals begin Tuesday at Cramton Bowl.

CECIL — Sami Nesbitt scored 11 points to lead the Knights (12-13) in the AISA Class AA, Region 1 quarterfinals. Madisyn Kennedy, Bailey Williams and Sommer Sears added 10 points each. Macon-East meets Coosa Valley in the semifinals at noon Friday. The Knights were already assured of their third state quarterfinal appearance in 12 years.

PHENIX CITY — Sara Young had 13 points and Jamey Joseph eight to lead the Warriors (24-2) in the Class AAA, Region 1 quarterfinals. Lee-Scott takes on Tuscaloosa Academy at 3 p.m. Friday at Chattahoochee Valley Community College.
PHENIX CITY — Kaitlyn Sampson had 15 points for Edgewood (13-12) against defending state champion Springwood (18-5) in Class AAA, Region 1.

CECIL — John Taylor had 18 points and Wade Howard 13 to spark the Rebels (7-10) in the AISA Class AA, Region 1 playoffs. Jon Johnson added eight points, nine rebounds and five steals. Lowndes faces Autauga Academy at 10:30 a.m. Friday in the semifinals. The Rebels sealed a fifth straight berth in the state quarterfinals.

CECIL — Tavis Billups’ 23 points led the Knights (28-0) in their AISA Class AA, Region 1 opener. Christian Lewis added 14 points and Logan Goree scored 10. Macon-East hosts Restoration at 1:30 p.m. Friday in the semifinals.

PHENIX CITY — Davis Thompson scored 12 points for the Warriors (20-6) in the Class AAA, Region 1 tournament. J.C. Bush and Brady Davidson had six points each for the Wildcats (3-22). Lee-Scott faces Tuscaloosa Academy at 4:30 p.m. Friday at Chattahoochee Valley community College.
ECLECTIC — On Tuesday, Terrance Head had 16 points and Tyric Belyeu 13 for the Panthers (8-10), who host Beulah on Friday. ACA (4-16) hosts Prattville Christian on Friday.

Maia Hill had 19 points on 7-of-10 shooting and the Hawks (13-4) won despite shooting 29 percent. Hill was 4-for-4 on 3-pointers. Jenna Dorman scored 18 points, while Juliette Harp had nine points and 18 rebounds. Jasmine Pitchford led Rust (1-17) with 15 points. Huntingdon plays at Covenant on Friday.
LaGRANGE, Ga. — Andre Ashley scored 14 points to lead Huntingdon (2-15, 0-6 USA South), which visits Greensboro College on Saturday. Justyn Olson had 17 points for the Panthers (11-8, 4-4).

articleBody.value: Alabama State athletic director Melvin Hines remains in full support of his head football coach – Brian Jenkins.

In a letter posted last week on ASU’s athletic website, Hines spoke highly of Jenkins, saying he and the “university leadership stand firmly behind Coach Jenkins and all of his staff with enthusiastic solidarity and support as they gear up for the 2017 season.”

The Hornets are 10-12 in their two seasons under Jenkins since he replaced Reggie Barlow. Jenkins suffered his first losing season ever as ASU went 4-7 last season, but Hines is optimistic about the football program’s future under the coach he lured from Bethune-Cookman to lead the Hornets.
ASU will renew its rivalry with Tuskegee to open the 2017 season Sept. 2 at ASU Stadium.

“Coach Jenkins has been extremely transparent and cooperative in assisting Alabama State University athletics in many ways and has especially helped us maintain an environment of compliance from the very onset of his arrival at the university,” Hines said in the letter.
Hines applauded Jenkins for reporting a recruiting violation to the NCAA last year. Jenkins served a one-game suspension that came against then-winless Mississippi Valley State.
The Hornets won, 56-24, with wide receiver coach Allen Suber serving as head coach.
“It takes an honest and forthright person to do that, and we commend (Jenkins) for his sterling character and the fine example he set for all of our coaching staff,” Hines said.

“We want all of our coaches to know and follow the rules outlined by the NCAA. And, more importantly, we want more men and women like Coach Jenkins who are honest and strong enough to admit that when they do make mistakes, they ‘own up to them’ and correct them.”

Jenkins came to ASU having won 46 games in five seasons at Bethune-Cookman. The three-time MEAC coach of the year won at least a share of four MEAC titles, earned three FCS playoff berths and captured two HBCU national titles, but he hasn’t been nearly as successful at ASU.

He agreed to a three-year deal with a base salary of $175,000 the first year, $200,000 the second year and $250,000 in the third and final year according to his contract obtained by WSFA-TV through the Freedom of Information Act.
The university’s board of trustees approved a two-year option as well back in February 2015. ASU had high hopes he’d deliver ASU its first SWAC title since 2004, but it hasn’t happened.
Southern handed ASU its worst loss in 54 years, 64-6, last season but Alabama State closed out the year with a 53-20 win over Miles College in the Turkey Day Classic.

Instead of discusses the wins and losses, Hines took the opportunity to recognize Jenkins for improving the football team’s Academic Progress Rate scores and his community service. ASU scored a 932 for the 2014-15 scoring period after receiving Level 3 penalties the previous academic year.

“I take pride in pointing out that since Coach Jenkins' arrival at ASU, he has worked hard to have the football team removed off of the NCAA's Academic Progress Rate (APR) probation and raised the profile and intellect of the type of student-athletes that put on the ASU football uniform,” Hines said.
ASU has seven players graduate in December – Brandon Barnes, JaQuez Bowser, Edward Murray, Bradley Street, Kadeem Thomas, Jylan Ware and Kerry Williams.

“In addition to the successes he has made in the classroom, Coach Jenkins has accomplished a myriad of positive achievements in the community, which make our students and ASU ‘shine’ a positive light in the public eye,” Hines continued. “Being well-rounded citizens is the hallmark of what we do at the university and within its department of athletics.”

articleBody.value: AUBURN – Auburn now has three members of the 2017 Senior Bowl roster.

Robert Leff, the starter at right tackle throughout the 2016 season, was added to the roster Tuesday afternoon and Auburn officials confirmed the news on Twitter after the first practice session. AuburnUndercover.com was the first to report this news.

Leff now joins defensive tackle Montravius Adams and defensive back Rudy Ford on the practice field in Mobile, Alabama to perform in front of several NFL scouts as they attempt to be drafted in the coming months. Carl Lawson, who is projected to a selection in the first two rounds of the 2017 NFL Draft, was given an invitation by the Senior Bowl committee but that invite had to be pulled a day later because Lawson was not a graduate yet because he plans to graduate in May and not December.

After a redshirt season and three years as a backup, Leff established himself as one of Auburn’s most reliable offensive lineman and arguably the Tigers’ most effective run blocker throughout the 2016 season.
“It's been great for me and for everybody else it can be an example of how hard work put in over time will lead to success,” Leff said earlier this month before the 2017 Sugar Bowl in New Orleans.

The Fairhope, Ala., native, who earned his degree in mechanical engineering in December, has gone from the sixth offensive lineman in goal line situations in the 2015 season to being a player ESPN NFL Draft analyst Mel Kiper says will likely be a draftee in 2017.

"I don't think he's going to go undrafted; I think he will get drafted," Kiper said in a teleconference last week. "I would say right now he ends up getting drafted somewhere around the fifth (or) sixth round. I wouldn't be surprised to see him go somewhere on Day 3. As a matter of fact I think he will. I really think he will."

Leff was a second-team All-SEC selection by The Associated Press and is one of two offensive linemen, along with Alex Kozan, Auburn will be forced to replace starting with this spring. When Leff was given the opportunity to start last spring, not many envisioned the idea that the 290-pound prospect would be a major loss to Herb Hand’s offensive line unit.

“I came to Auburn because of Auburn, not just because of football or the coaches,” he said. “I was planning on coming to Auburn before I even had any interest in athletic scholarships. Really, I had no plans on transferring. Never even thought of it.”

articleBody.value: Capt. Erik Gonsalves' red and white F-16 fighter jet made a graceful landing at Dannelly Field on Wednesday a few months ahead of the rest of his Thunderbird flight team, who are the headliners for April's air show in Montgomery.

Jumping out of the cockpit, he was happy to be greeted by a warm Alabama day. He had just left winter temperatures in Pittsburgh and flew here to survey the area for the spring show at Maxwell Air Force Base.

Gonsalves was here for just a day, but he and his crew chief had a lot to inspect since the last time the area hosted an air show was seven years ago. He talked with Maxwell's air show team, inspected the support facilities and made sure everyone is "on track" to have a successful air show.
Brand new to the elite Thunderbirds, Gonsalves previously flew the A10 and is thrilled to live out his childhood dream and be a part of the famous aerial acrobatics team.

"We have the coolest job in the world in my opinion," Gonsalves said. "The ability to go from place to place and showcase the mission of the Air Force, I can't think of anything more special than that.
"I remember as a kid, I watched the Thunderbirds fly and I wondered what that would be like one day if I could do that."
Now as the face of the Air Force, he has the opportunity to share his story with children, schools, celebrities and other countries and what the mission of the Air Force is.
He's also excited to return to Montgomery and Maxwell where he attended a professional military course at Air University. He will also be serving as the team's narrator for the air show April 8-9.

The other Thunderbird pilots and ground crew are gearing for the show during what is now their practice and training period. They fly for two hours each day, 10 hours a week. Their season will go from March until November and unusually include about 70 shows.

Maxwell Air Force Base Open House and Air Show on April 8 and 9 is open to the public and will feature a unique spin by bringing an "international flavor" with the French jet team flying in aerobatic formations along with the Thunderbirds.
The show will also be celebrating the 100th year anniversary of when the United States entered World War I and static WWI aircraft will also make an appearance.
About 110,000 visitors are expected to arrive for the show beginning April 8 and last through the weekend. April 7 has been set aside for local schools to visit and talk with the pilots.

articleBody.value: COLUMBIA, S.C.  – Frank Martin would prefer to never coach against Austin Wiley again.

After watching Auburn’s freshman center go for his first double-double in his college basketball career in the Tigers embarrassing 96-68 loss Tuesday night, the South Carolina head coach had one question regarding Wiley.
“Holy cow. Can he declare?” Martin asked half-jokingly in regards to Wiley's NBA Draft status following this current 2016-17 season. “Whoa is he good or what?”

When informed the answer to whether Wiley can declare for the draft was no, Martin had a concise conclusion. As a point of fact, Wiley will not be 19 years old before the 2017 NBA Draft and therefore not eligible, a fact that illuminated why he, his mother and Auburn head coach Bruce Pearl set into motion this early enrollment plan months ago.
“Well, then that’s a problem,” Martin said.

In the tunnel before Auburn players got on the bus to head home following the 29-point loss at Colonial Life Arena, Martin was talking with Wiley and several other Auburn players to let them know what he thought of their development.

“I just told him after the game (that) he is real good. It’s scary how good he can get,” Martin said. “Let’s not forget that six weeks ago he’s probably walking down the hallway of a school and now he’s out there competing at the highest level of college basketball. He’s trying to learn stuff that some guys have been practicing for three, four months. He’s good.”

Wiley’s mother, Vickie Orr, a former three-time All-American, was told by several college coaches during the recruitment process to not go to Auburn because Pearl was incapable of coaching a post player. Wiley wears the same number 50 his mother made famous enough for it to be retired at Auburn Arena and she trusted Pearl to guide her son however long he’s in college.

“It’s so hard to get him the ball right now because we’re not doing a good job getting it to him,” Pearl said Tuesday night. “That’s on me because I need to do a better job getting him the ball. He does a great job of getting to the foul line. I thought we got really good play out of the center position.”

The 18-year-old center, who was named SEC Freshman of the Week Monday, was the Tigers only consistent early offense and rebounding Tuesday night with 10 points. Wiley finished with his first career double-double Tuesday night (10 points and 11 rebounds) after getting his 10th rebound with over 10 minutes left in the game.

“At first I was just happy to out there and trying not to mess up but now I’m just realizing that I can be a big part in whether we win or lose,” Wiley said after the loss. “I need to get better and better and right now that is happening.”

Martin, who in his career has coached former No. 2 overall pick Michael Beasley, was astonished by how the 6-foot-10 center made it look easy on both ends of the floor despite getting little help his youthful teammates in Auburn’s biggest blowout loss of the season.
“Great hands, good footwork, good demeanor, has a desire for the ball, doesn’t stand and wait for it, doesn’t shy away from contact,” Martin said.

Martin, who built his South Carolina squad into a top tier SEC program in his fifth year, believes Pearl’s 2016 recruiting class, which now includes Wiley along with Mustapha Heron, Jared Harper and Tuesday night’s leading scorer Anfernee McLemore, will begin the turnaround at Auburn.
“(Wiley is) good. The SEC has a problem dealing with him and actually all the freshman because they’ve got a great group of guys,” Martin said.

content.author: Matthew Stevens, Montgomery Advertiser
content.headline: Frank Martin on Auburn’s Austin Wiley: ‘It’s scary how good he can get’
content.description: South Carolina coach Frank Martin raves about Auburn freshman Austin Wiley after his first career double-double.

articleBody.value: Here’s something to crow about: The Year of the Rooster is just ahead on the Chinese zodiac, and the official kickoff for the Chinese New Year will be on Saturday. However, here in the River Region, we‘re getting started a little early.
One of them is a private Troy University event in Montgomery to celebrate Confucius Institute and the Janice Hawkins Cultural Arts Park on Thursday.

While you can’t attend this event without an invitation, it’s important to note that Troy University is giving two terracotta warrior statues to the Montgomery Museum of Fine Arts and recognizing Troy's Confucius Classroom partners. The program also features performances by Troy University faculty and students, along with Confucius Classroom students from LAMP and Indian Springs schools.

Established in 2007, the Confucius Institute at Troy University promotes understanding of Chinese language and culture and is the only such institute in Alabama with a statewide mission. The Institute also serves an economic development role and has sponsored 18 trips to China for state business leaders, government officials, teachers and students since 2008. The Institute also partners with schools in Montgomery, Pike Road and the Birmingham area through the Confucius Classrooms program.
Unless you’re one of the lucky invitees, you won’t be able to attend this one, but there are other local events in and around the River Region over the next couple of weeks.

Another Troy University Chinese New Year event takes place Friday, and this one is open to the public for a small price. Members of Troy University’s Chinese Students and Scholars Association will celebrate on the Troy Campus in the Trojan Center ballrooms.
The annual event, also called Spring Festival, welcomes everyone and features traditional performances and food.

Tickets to the event are $15 ($10 for students), and may be purchased from the International Program Office located in the basement of Hawkins Hall, in the Trojan Center food court during lunch and at the doors, which open at 5 p.m.

“This is the most important festival for the Chinese people and has more than 4,000 years of history,” said Ruifeng Wang, CSSA’s president. “It is similar to Christmas in the West with families coming together to celebrate.”
The slate of entertainment includes language programs, song and dance performances, piano, violin, Hulusi and other instrumental performances. Door prizes will also be awarded during the evening.
For more information, please contact the International Programs Office at 334-670-3335, or via email to cssa@troy.edu.
CACC Chinese New Year at Frazer

If you’re interested in attending the Central Alabama Association of Chinese (CAAC) 2017 Montgomery Chinese New Year celebration festival, you should act fast. The event is scheduled for Saturday at 2:30 p.m. at the Fellowship Hall of Frazer Methodist Church, 6000 Atlanta Hwy, Montgomery.
According to organizers, this event is primarily for members and guests of the CACC, but a limited number of tickets may be available for sale.

The celebration will begin with a Chinese New Year celebration cultural performance. Attendees will be entertained by children's happy new year show, Chinese folk and ethnic group dances, singing, traditional Chinese musical instrument performance, children's talent show, and a comedy show.  In addition, children will be given new year "red envelopes" (with lucky money inside) at the celebration.  A buffet style Chinese New Year feast will be served afterwards.
For more information and possibly to get tickets, please e-mail ypwang_2000@yahoo.com or call at 334-546-3200.
A night of classical Chinese dance brings ancient culture back to life at the Montgomery Performing Arts Centre on Feb. 2 at 7:30 p.m.

Shen Yun, the multimillion-dollar spectacle of “dazzling backdrops” and “glorious melodies” of Chinese song and dance, is bringing its 2017 tour to Montgomery just in time for Chinese New Year. Shen Yun dances recount ancient myths, bygone heroes, or celestial paradises. Whether set in the past or in contemporary China, every dance embodies traditional Chinese values.

Tickets for the show range from $73-$153 and are available online through Ticketmaster or tickets.shenyun.com/, or through the MPAC box office. For more information, call 888-974-3698 or 800-745-3000.

The Montgomery Advertiser is currently offering an Insider Event for a chance to win tickets to Shen Yun. One winner will be selected on or around Jan. 30. The winner will receive two tickets to the MPAC performance. Must be 18 or older to enter. Information on how to enter are available online at montgomeryadvertiser.com.
Auburn University at Montgomery’s annual Chinese Lunar New Year and Lantern Festival Celebration will take place at 2:30 p.m. on Feb. 11 at Alcazar Shrine Temple, 555 Eastern Blvd., Montgomery.

Guests can enjoy Chinese culture, food and entertainment. The celebration, hosted by AUM’s Confucius Institute in partnership with the Central Alabama Association of Chinese (CAAC), will feature numerous performances.  A dinner featuring traditional Chinese New Year delicacies will follow this year’s celebration performance. Before dinner, performers from AUMCI and CAAC as well as from other partners will treat the audience to lively music and colorful dancing, including youth and adult dragon dancing. Among the highlights will be a performance on the guzheng (the traditional Chinese plucked zither) by Qing Li, an award-winning professional Chinese musician who is currently a visiting professor at Auburn University, and Chinese folk dances by Janice Yang, who holds a master’s degree in Chinese folk dance.

“Chinese Lunar New Year, also called the Spring Festival, is the most important of the traditional Chinese holidays,” says Dr. Eric Yang, dean of the AUM Confucius Institute and director of East Asia Initiatives. “It is the most anticipated celebration of the year in China. We are excited to be collaborating again with the CAAC for this festive celebration since our two organizations share the goal of increasing understanding about China in Alabama.”
Ticket prices for this event are: Non-CAAC member, $12; CAAC member, $8; students with ID, $8; children ages 3-10, $5; Children under 3, free.

The deadline to RSVP tickets is officially Feb. 6, but you should order your tickets now. There will be no tickets available on site. Seats are limited and based on first come, first served. For more information, write to confucius@aum.edu or 334-244-3012 for registration and ticket information.
For more information about the Confucius Institute and the festival celebration, please visit www.aum.edu/confucius, or contact Dr. Eric Yang at 334-244-3955, wyang@aum.edu.

articleBody.value: Donald Trump bragged, via tweet, that he’s the Ernest Hemingway of Twitter. Unfortunately for us, the new president possesses neither the courage nor the self-control of Hemingway, winner of the 1954 Nobel Prize in Literature for writing unforgettably about bravery under fire. As the problems created by Trump-tweets pile up, the source of Trump’s addiction to Twitter has become all too clear. Eugene Robinson, the Pulitzer Prize-winning Washington Post columnist, described it in words worthy of John Steinbeck: “Trump’s Twitter tantrums are a message of weakness.”

When I read Trump’s recent Twitter attack on Congressman John Lewis, the venerated civil rights leader who, despite vivid memories and bloody images to the contrary, Trump had the temerity to write he was “all talk, talk, talk – no action or results,” I was reminded of the lecture Toni Morrison gave when she won the Nobel Prize in 1993. Like the speeches of two previous Nobel Prize-winners, William Faulkner and John Steinbeck, her lecture extolled the power of language in explaining and validating human experience. “We die,” she observed. “That may be the meaning of life. But we do language. That may be the measure of our lives.”

Echoing George Orwell, Morrison warned that “the systematic looting of language can be recognized by the tendency of its users to forego its nuanced, complex, mid-wifery properties for menace and subjugation.” Foreshadowing Trump’s grade school twitter-burns, she described “language that drinks blood, laps vulnerabilities, tucks its fascist boots under crinolines of respectability and patriotism as it moves relentlessly toward the bottom line and the bottomed-out mind.”

At her popular blog BrainPickings.org, Maria Popova praised Morrison’s lecture as “perhaps our most powerful manifesto for the responsibility embedded in how we wield the tool that stands as the hallmark of our species.” I agree with this assessment, and with Morrison’s Orwell-like admonition. “Whether it is the malignant language of law-without-ethics, or language designed for the estrangement of minorities,” she said, “it must be rejected, altered and exposed.”

I also agree with Kyle Sammin, the lawyer and writer from Pennsylvania who advised Trump to delete his Twitter account, quoting Calvin Coolidge: “The words of the President have an enormous weight and ought not to be used indiscriminately.” As Morrison noted, Abraham Lincoln provides an even better example of presidential brevity: “When a President of the United States thought about the graveyard his country had become, and said, ‘The world will little note nor long remember what we say here. But it will never forget what they did here,’ his simple words are exhilarating in their life-sustaining properties because they refused to encapsulate the reality of 600, 000 dead men in a cataclysmic race war.”

By the time Republicans convened in Cleveland last summer, I had already blogged that the Republican nominee for president was the antithesis of Lincoln. He’s no Coolidge either. Hell, he may not be as good as Dan Quayle, who at least had the sense to stop explaining when he misspelled “potato” at a Trenton, New Jersey elementary school during the 1992 campaign.

As Arthur Delaney pointed out in a recent Huffington Post headline, “Donald Trump Can’t Stop Tweeting Mean Things About People.” America’s new president is like a gambler on an all-night binge in Atlantic City, compulsively feeding nickel-and-dime tweets, retweets and mentions into the slot-machine of his ego.

Since he shows no sign of stopping, Trump would do well to follow the example of John Steinbeck, whose son Thom – also a writer – had this to say about the virtue of authorial self-control during a 2012 interview with Alexander Jaffee. “Ultimately,” he noted, “the greatest amount of time in all writing is spent editing. My father said there’s only one trick to writing, and that’s not writing, that’s writing and rewriting and rewriting and rewriting. Like sculpture. I mean, the first thing off the top of your head isn’t the most brilliant thing you ever thought of. And then when you’re writing about it, when you want others to understand what you’re still talking about, then it really requires that you edit yourself really, really well, so that other people can comprehend it.”

Sadly, Trump has a problem in this area that no amount of self-editing can fix. Describing Steinbeck’s honesty, Thom wrote: “Everything he wrote had truth to it. That’s what he was addicted to. He was addicted to the truth.” As demonstrated by Twitter attacks on true American heroes like Lewis, Trump has the opposite addiction.

Stephen Cooper is a former D.C. public defender who worked as an assistant federal public defender in Alabama between 2012 and 2015. He writes full-time and lives in Woodland Hills, California. Follow him on Twitter @SteveCooperEsq.

articleBody.value: Nick Saban has moved on, but that 35-31 loss Jan. 9 to Clemson in Tampa still stings.
“We’re disappointed that we didn’t finish the game, but it was a great football game,” said Saban in an NFL Network interview Tuesday from Senior Bowl practice in Mobile.

“Clemson did a great job, made the plays they needed to make at the end and we didn’t, but I think when that happens, it’s time for everybody to go back and say, ‘What can I do to make the organization better.’ I think that’s what we’re all doing so that we can try to improve.”

I just recently watched the College Football Playoff national title game again on DVR. To watch the Alabama defense that gave up fewer than 17 points in 12 games surrender 21 in the fourth quarter to the Tigers is still crazy.

When you see the amazing catches Mike Williams and Jordan Leggett made, Clemson had to really dig deep to pull out the win against the top seed and unbeaten Crimson Tide. The teams that have beaten Alabama have done that, but not every team has a guy like Deshaun Watson or Chad Kelly.
There have been complaints that Clemson ran pick plays with its receivers to win with the final one coming on Hunter Renfrow’s touchdown catch with a second remaining.

“We knew that they were going to play cover zero inside the five,” said Watson immediately after the game in an ESPN interview. “All we needed was a good pick by (Artavis Scott) and (Scott) picked (Marlon Humphrey) and Renfrow got in the end zone and I just kind of threw the ball to make sure he caught it. That’s what he did. It’s something we worked on all year long and it was the perfect time to call it.”
First of all, every school should have those rub plays in their playbook
Second, the game is geared for the offense. Third, you’re not going to line up man-to-man and beat Alabama on every play. The Tide has more talent than anyone in the country.
So you better have some back shoulder throws and pick plays to offset the Tide's talent advantage.
In the end, Clemson winning was good for college football because it gave the handful of schools who have a legitimate shot to beat Alabama more optimism that they too can knock off the Tide.
Florida State is one of those schools. Can’t wait to see that Sept. 2 matchup at the new Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta to open the 2017 season.
Too early to predict how that game will go, but I’m certain Alabama will take heed to Saban’s look-in-the-mirror message and be ready to play.

articleBody.value: Since 1959, Cuba has been ruled by the brothers Fidel and Raul Castro, a pair of communist thugs who nationalized that country’s industries and used violence and terror to silence political opponents. I vividly remember my first visit to Cuba nearly 10 years ago. In a country where private ownership of property was illegal, the poverty was stark and omnipresent. If a person was loitering on the side of the road, government law mandated that any passing driver offer the loiterer a ride, since “the people” owned the automobile.

On that trip a decade ago, I recall hearing a four-hour speech by Castro in which he touted Cuba’s “leadership” in the area of health and medicine, but when I looked into the eyes of the Cuban people on the streets of Havana, I could see their hopelessness and desperation. I listened to that propaganda-filled speech and wondered when the country of over 11 million citizens would have an opportunity to live and thrive as a free people.

I believe Fidel Castro’s death on Nov. 25 marks a unique opportunity for the U.S., and Alabama in particular, to influence the economic and political future of Cuba, a nation located a mere 90 miles off the coast of Florida. Raul Castro serves as president, but is 85 years old and has pledged to not seek re-election in 2018. The end of the Castro regime is imminent, and now is the time for the U.S. to strengthen its cultural and economic ties with the Cuban people, as they slowly gain political freedom.
WEATHER UPDATE: 17 tornadoes hit central Alabama, 3 in River Region

This past November, I visited the country again as a member of “Engage Cuba,” an organization dedicated to improving Cuban-American relations by ending the embargo the U.S. government has had in place on trade between the two countries for the past 55 years. If the embargo’s aim has been to achieve democratization in Cuba, then the embargo has clearly failed.

But now, with Fidel’s death and a new president set to replace Raul in 2018, American policymakers have a tremendous opening to put pressure on the remnants of the Castro regime by allowing American companies to do business in Cuba.

My recent visit allowed me see first-hand the economic opportunities for American businesses, and especially for those located in Alabama. As Cuba slowly comes out from the shadow of the Castro regime and moves toward a market-based economy, the opportunities for enterprising Alabama businesses and farmers to provide goods and services to the Cuban people are nearly endless.

For example, a report from Engage Cuba and the U.S. Agricultural Coalition for Cuba observes that Cuba imported $78 million worth of poultry in 2014. Among the American states, Alabama is the second-largest poultry exporter, shipping out $478 million worth of broiler meat in 2015. Yet the Congressional embargo severely limits the ability of Alabama companies to access the Cuban market for poultry.
READ MORE: Alabama  Ag expert recalls meeting Fidel Castro

As Cuba modernizes its infrastructure, the country will also desperately need the affordable timber that Alabama’s $21 billion forestry industry can supply. With Mobile’s port only 628 miles away from Havana, even geographically, Alabama is well-positioned to lead economic engagement with Cuba.

I am convinced that opening political and economic relations with Cuba is the right course of action both for the United States and for the Cuban people, who have lived under a political dictatorship for over five decades. Congress’s embargo policy has not worked. A new, forward-looking strategy of engagement is necessary. For Alabama, this represents a unique opportunity: We have the products, the port, and the willingness to be a leading trading partner with Cuba in the 21st century.

Gerald Dial represents District 13 in the Alabama Senate, which includes all or parts of Randolph, Lee, Cleburne, Clay, Cherokee and Chambers counties. He serves as chairman of the Senate Health and Human Services Committee.

articleBody.value: It’s only a matter of time before the U.S. Supreme Court throws out Alabama’s sentencing scheme that allows a judge to override a jury’s recommended sentence in a death penalty case, said state Sen. Dick Brewbaker.
On Monday, SCOTUS declined to review the cases of three Alabama death row inmates who challenged judicial override.
Alabama is the last state in which a judge has the ability reverse a jury's capital sentence. In January 2016, SCOTUS struck down Florida’s similar sentencing scheme.
“They took a pass on Alabama’s law, but I still believe that sooner or later the [Supreme] Court is going to strike this down,” Brewbaker said during an editorial board meeting with the Advertiser. ​

In lieu of waiting for the courts to act, Brewbaker, R-Montgomery, pre-filed a bill in December that would prohibit judges from overriding a jury’s sentence in capital cases. As it stands, Alabama’s sentencing law defines the jury’s sentence as “an advisory verdict recommended to the trial court.”
In part, Brewbaker’s proposed bill would change that language to say “a verdict.” The jury’s sentence would no longer be advisory or a recommendation.
Though he supports the death penalty, Brewbaker said he thinks there are problems with the way it’s practiced in Alabama.

“By logical extension why couldn’t the judge override the jury’s determination of innocence or guilt? Why is it any better for a judge to override a sentence of his peers who make those recommendations? … My opinion, and apparently the opinion of 49 other sovereign states, is that that decision should remain with the jury,” he said.
He added that having the option of judicial override presents political pressure for elected judges to appear tough on crime, especially during election years.
“That’s going to be something on their mind, even if they’re not conscious of it,” Brewbaker said.
Sen. Hank Sanders, D-Selma, has also submitted a bill that would abolish judicial override.

Out of the 184 currently residing on Alabama's death row, 95 are there as a result of judicial override, according to records kept by the Equal Justice Initiative. Brewbaker said that if the law were to pass, it would not affect the death row status of those 95.

On Dec. 8, the state executed Ronald Smith, who was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole in 1995 but a judge reversed the jury's sentence and ordered his death. Smith's attorneys unsuccessfully appealed to the Supreme Court for a last-minute stay of execution based on the court's ruling to strike down Florida’s similar sentencing scheme.

Brewbaker has sponsored death penalty reform legislation in the past. During last year’s legislative session, Brewbaker introduced a bill aimed at creating an innocence commission. The legislation would have allowed death row inmates to be exonerated if they could prove their innocence. The bill ultimately failed.
“I’m a believer in the death penalty,” Brewbaker said. “I’m not a believer of the way we’re practicing in Alabama. I don’t think our system is nearly as sound as we think it is.”

content.author: Kelsey Davis, Montgomery Advertiser
