articleBody.value: Have an event or concert listing that you'd like added? There are two ways to do so. Fill out the required fields at events.montgomeryadvertiser.com as well as sending information to Shannon Heupel at sheupel@gannett.com.

Montgomery Film Festival at the Capri: The Montgomery Film Festival showcases the works of amateur and professional filmmakers within Alabama, the US and internationally in short film & feature length format. $8 tickets for Capri Members, $10 tickets for General Admission. Line-up can be found at montgomeryfilmfestival.com. Check out capritheatre.org to see what's coming to the theater.

Fee-Fee Redmon at Pure Artistry: 9-11:30 p.m. on Jan. 28 at Pure Artistry, 142 W Jeff Davis Ave., Montgomery. Latrisha Redmon, affectionately known to her friends and family as "Fee-Fee", possesses a multitude of talent and to that she honors God for the gift(s). She has traveled extensively in the States as well as overseas to places such as Japan, India and South America, inspiring others thru the use of her gifts and talents. She was the drummer for National Recording Artist, Leon Timbo and has shared the stage with various other recording artists throughout the years. It was only until recently that she's begun to branch off into doing some singing of her own. She's always been fascinated with the acoustic guitar and began to play around with one she found at a thrift store. One of her friends took notice of the used guitar she was playing around on and decided to purchase her a new one for her birthday. That was the push she needed to keep on learning it. Fee-Fee never intended on being an "artist". But recently, she's found herself in that role, as she sought to inspire others through every gift given to her. Hence she's adopted the mantra and hashtag, #iLive2Inspire. Admission $10/adv. $15/door. All sales final. No exchanges. No refunds.

Look Here, Look Now: Fashion, Costume, and Style in Art: Now through Jan. 29, at Montgomery Museum of Fine Arts. This installation includes works of art from the MMFA’s permanent collection on how clothing or fashion may convey aesthetic intention and individuality.

Kowaliga Idol: VFW Wetumpka, 100 Otter Track Road, Wetumpka, 7 p.m.-midnight. We are proud to once again host Kowaliga Idol, with Kowaliga Country 97.5! If you're a singer and you know it, then your voice will surely show it! If you're not a singer, come on out and enjoy some really talented voices in the competition! Visit http://www.wkga975.com/kowaliga-idol.html for more information.

Chamber music concert:  Tuesday, Feb. 9: Faure Piano Quartette.  Concert begins 7:30 p.m. at the Wilson Auditorium of the Montgomery Museum of Fine Arts. Reception following concert. Tickets may be purchased by calling 334-277-3505, on the Internet at montgomerychambermusic.org, or at the door. Special prices are available for students.

To Kill A Mockingbird: Prattville’s Way Off Broadway Theatre announces its production of Harper Lee’s To Kill a Mockingbird, adapted by Christopher Sergel, which will be produced by special arrangement with The Dramatic Publishing Company of Woodstock, Illinois. The play will be directed by Sam Wallace, who last directed The Curious Savage at WOBT. This play, based on the Pulitzer Prize winning novel by Alabama author Harper Lee, is a coming of age story loosely based on Lee’s family and friends and deals with social and racial issues of the Deep South. The critically acclaimed novel was made into a movie which received several Oscars, was adapted for the stage and presented in the U.S. and U.K. and has been included in the educational curriculum in schools throughout the United States for many years. To Kill a Mockingbird will open on Thursday, Feb. 9, at 7:30 p.m. and there will be a reception to meet the cast and crew following the play. The production will run Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays on Feb. 10–26, with a special performance on Valentine’s Day. For further information, please contact the Cultural Arts and Special Events Office at 334-595-0854 or visit the website at wobt.prattvilleal.gov.

The Love Run: Join us for our 2017 Love Run 5k. Deemed "the toughest 5k in Montgomery", our race was designed intentionally to simulate the challenges and hardships our children have had to face in their lives. As you cross the finish line atop Brantwood's hill, our children will be there cheering you on all the way.  Early registration is $25 with the proceeds providing food, clothing, and shelter for our 30 children. All runners will receive goodie bags, t-shirts, and a fabulous breakfast catered by Wind Creek Good to Go food truck. Registration can be found on Brantwood's webpage and onwww.active.com. For additional information, please call Krystal at 334-549-5988.

Black History Month Musical Program: The public is invited to share our annual Black History Month Musical Program on Sunday, Feb. 12, at 2:30 p.m. at St. Stephens Baptist Church, 1609 Withers St., Montgomery. Theme: “Oh magnify the Lord with me, and let us exalt His name together,” - Psalm 34:3. Featuring St. Stephens Baptist Church Mass Choir, Lilly Bapt. Church Male Chorus, North Montgomery Bapt. Church Choir, The Church of Encouragement Choir, The Wright Brothers, Faith Full Gospel Mime Team, Macedonia Bapt. Church Praise Dance Ministry, all of Montgomery, AL; Mt. Zion Community Church Choir of Birmingham, Greater White Church Choir of Shorter, Mike and Family of Union Springs, the Tones of Harmony of Merietta, Florida; Shiloh Bapt. Church of Hope Hull, and some of Montgomery’s and surrounding areas’ finest soloists and choirs. Our dynamic mistress of ceremony Sis. Shirley J. White, St. Stephens Baptist Church. Dinner will be served. Sponsor Shirley J. White, St. Stephens Baptist Church Family, Rev. Jones, pastor.

Romeo & Juliet at the Capri: Capri Theatre's pre-Valentine's Day Party featuring food, drink and Franco Zeffirelli's classic adaptation of Romeo and Juliet. One Night Only. Sunday, February 12 at the Capri Theatre. Reception at 6:00 film at 7:30 p.m. All Tickets $30. Period Costumes Encouraged. Proceeds to benefit the Capri Theatre. $20 of ticket tax-deductible.

Tokens of Affection: Red Door Theare in Union Springs presents Tokens of Affection on Feb. 16-19, written by Topher Payne and directed by Kathryn Adams Wood. Dinner at 6 p.m. on Feb. Feb. 16-18, with play at 7:30 p.m., matinee play Feb. 19 at 2:30 p.m. Dinner $15, Play $15. 334-738-8687.

Moonstruck - Works on Paper from the MMFA Collection: Now through Feb. 19, at Montgomery Museum of Fine Arts. In this installation of works from the Museum’s collection of works on paper, artists use the moon as both a compositional device and symbol.
Life Drawing: February life drawing class is Sunday, Feb. 19, 2:30-5 p.m. at The Sanctuary, 432 S. Goldthwaite St., Montgomery. Tickets available at www.eventbrite.com.

Fashion Variety Show: Feb. 24, 6-9:15 p.m. at My Place Events and Catering.  The Fashion Variety Show produced and directed by Derricius Chambers and DaQuentin Davis will showcase various genres of pop culture, fashion and music displayed through performances (singing, dancing, acts and modeling) onstage and runway. This event will commemorate the 30th Anniversary of MAO and the unveiling of its new name: Medical Advocacy & Outreach. This event will be a great source for entertainment and networking. The evening will feature work from DaQuentin Davis, Dreeck Breon, Antowan Fleeton, Christella Williams, CiCi Cotton, and many more talented tastemakers. Tickets are avaiable for free admission, for tickets please contact DQ Davis334-386-0856 or Derricius Breon 334-386-6426. This is a mature audience event.

Princess Stories for school-age children: ADT will offer special school performances of the “The Princess Stories” on Friday, March 3 at 9:30 and 11:30 a.m. at Troy University’s Davis Theatre at special prices of $7 per child. Performances are geared toward school age children in the River Region.  The action packed “Princess Stories” feature “Pocahontas”, “Aladdin”, “The Sleeping Beauty” and the forerunner of a full length “Beauty and the Beast”.  The stories are colorful and exciting and will appeal to both boys and girls.  Make your reservations now by calling ADT at 334-241-2590 or email Brenda Dennis at adtdance1@gmail.com.

Alabama Angels Ride: Nasty Feet RC invites you all to attend our 1st annual Alabama Angels Ride on March 4, 10 a.m.-10 p.m. at Harley Davidson of Montgomery, 655 N. Eastern Blvd., Montgomery. In honor of our Angel...Joey Warrick. All proceeds benefit the Alabama Angels Pageant that will be held on March 11 in Montgomery at Frazer UMC. The pageant is for people (male and female) of all ages with Special Needs. The pageant provides the participants with their attire, make up, hair, lunch and all other aspects needed, for the participants and their family, for the day. Each participant will recieve a crown and other special gifts. The pageant is open statewide to all who want to participate

The Princess Stories and More: Back by popular demand, the Alabama Dance Theatre will present its 30th annual spring concert featuring “The Princess Stories and More”, on Saturday, March 4 at 2:30 p.m. (shortened children’s matinee of “Princess Stories” only), Saturday, March 4 at 7:30 p.m. and Sunday, March 5 at 2:30 p.m. at Troy University’s Davis Theatre for the Performing Arts. Performance tickets are $15-$30. We are offering a special ticket price for children ages 12 and under of $15. The action packed “Princess Stories” feature “Pocahontas”, “Aladdin”, “The Sleeping Beauty” and the forerunner of a full length “Beauty and the Beast”.  The stories are colorful and exciting and will appeal to both boys and girls.   For tickets, call 334-241-2800 or visit www.alabamadancetheatre.com. *After the Saturday matinee performance children can meet the princesses onstage for an additional $10 charge which will include a chance to win a beautiful pearl necklace and earring set, donated by Harold’s Fine Jewelry. The drawing for the pearls will be immediately following the Sunday performance. You do not have to be present to win.

Chamber music concert:  Tuesday, April 4: Quator Ebene.  Concert begins 7:30 p.m. at the Wilson Auditorium of the Montgomery Museum of Fine Arts. Tickets may be purchased by calling 334-277-3505, on the Internet at montgomerychambermusic.org, or at the door. Special prices are available for students. A pre-concert Spring supper will be held at the museum's Café M at 6 p.m. Tickets for the supper can be reserved by phone at 334-276-3505 or on the Internet at montgomerychambermusic.org

Poker for P-Pod: Saturday, April 22, 2 p.m. at It'll Do Tavern, 557 Eastern Blvd., Montgomery. Poker for P-Pod is a scholarship fundraiser for the Peyton Elizabeth Cox Memorial Scholarship which was created to honor the life and legacy of our beloved P-Pod. Peyton was a well-rounded mix of beauty, brains, and talent. Her love for softball only came second to her academics. We have created this scholarship to honor one graduating senior softball player from Wetumpka High School that we feel best represents Peyton and the things that were most important to her. The scholarship will be managed by Elmore County Community Foundation.

articleBody.value: —“Feeling Good,” as sung by Nina Simone
President Trump’s critics are finding it difficult to stay focused following a flurry of actions taken by the new American CEO.

In just the first working days of the new administration, the president has signed an executive order withdrawing from the negotiating process of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), aligning him with socialist independent Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-VT) and Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio), who broke with former President Obama over the agreement. Sen. John McCain (R-AZ) and Barack Obama oppose withdrawal. Strange bedfellows, indeed.

Trump has also reinstated the Mexico City Policy, which, writes CBS News, “required nongovernmental organizations to agree as a condition of receiving any federal funding that they ‘would neither perform nor actively promote abortion as a method of family planning in other nations.’” In addition, House Republicans say they will move to make the Hyde Amendment, which prevents the use of taxpayer dollars to pay for abortions, except to save the life of the woman, or if the pregnancy arises from incest or rape, permanent. They also plan to cut off federal funds from Planned Parenthood.
READ:  Brewbaker says sentencing reform inevitable

On Tuesday, Trump signed another executive order to advance the Keystone XL and Dakota pipelines. The Obama administration and environmental groups had opposed both projects, claiming they would harm the environment and contribute to America’s reliance on fossil fuels. Until alternative fuels are sufficiently available to replace fossil fuels, we should use what we have and wean ourselves totally from Middle East oil.

Taking a page from Abraham Lincoln and his “team of rivals,” Trump met Monday not only with a group of business executives, but also with union heads, who had endorsed Hillary Clinton for president. Trump told both groups he wants to create jobs, especially for the middle class. The union heads came out of the meeting in support of the president’s goal. When was the last time you can recall a union leader praising a Republican president?

It’s a new day for the media, too. Sean Spicer, the White House press secretary, signaled on Monday that the relationship between the White House and media is changing. Spicer announced that he would provide access via Skype to journalists working for news organizations “who may not have the convenience or funding to travel to Washington.”

By selecting reporters who rarely get to ask questions inside the briefing room and ignoring some who do (liberal newspaper reporters and broadcast and certain cable outlets), Spicer sent a signal that journalists who come at a Republican president from the left will no longer enjoy preferential treatment, which means the public might actually get useful information.

In the early days of this administration, Trump has shown he intends to follow through on his campaign promises. He believes — rightly — that in the past Republicans, even in the rare times when they have controlled all three branches of government as they do now, have been intimidated by Democrats and their media friends and cowered when faced with opposition and criticism.
WEATHER UPDATE: 17 tornadoes hit central Alabama, 3 in River Region

There will be more changes to come, including a nominee to the Supreme Court, action on school choice, which allows poor kids to escape failing schools, a new and more successful approach to fighting terrorism, immigration reform that, for starters, expels criminal aliens, properly vets those coming into the country and significantly reduces the flow of illegal immigrants. Who knows, we might even get a credible foreign policy that puts American interests first and no longer tries to impose American values on nations that have no foundation in democracy or religious and political pluralism.
Readers may email Cal Thomas at tcaeditors@tribpub.com.

content.author: Cal Thomas, Columnist
content.headline: Feeling good (so far)
content.description: Trump’s critics are finding it difficult to stay focused following a flurry of actions taken by the new American CEO.
